properties.name: Virginia Shipbuilding Corporation
properties.park: Jones Point Park - George Washington Memorial Parkway
properties.description: On April 17, 1917, the United States Shipping Board created the Emergency Fleet Corporation. The Virginia Shipbuilding Corporation of Alexandria, VA took advantage of the lucrative contracts offered.

properties.name: The Bull Moose in Winter: Theodore Roosevelt and World War I
properties.description: During the war years, Theodore Roosevelt advocated for direct U.S. involvement. His sons and daughters all found important roles, and made great sacrifices for the cause.

properties.name: Tank Training at Camp Colt
properties.description: On the same field where Pickett's Charge occurred 50 years earlier, Dwight Eisenhower trained troops in the new art of tank tactics.

properties.name: The Art of Camouflage
properties.description: Camouflage was first developed in France in 1914 by artist Lucien-Victor Guirand de Scévola and others. n the United States, this development took place a few years later, using the talents of the artists of the Cornish Colony in Cornish, New Hampshire, at the site of the present-day Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site.

properties.name: National Woman's Party Protests
properties.description: “When men are denied justice, they go to war. This is our war, only we are fighting it with banners instead of guns.” -Alice Paul

properties.name: Bonus Expeditionary Forces March on Washington
properties.description: In the depths of the Great Depression, a dramatic showdown between jobless WWI veterans, lawmakers, the police, and the Army played out in Washington, DC.

properties.name: Franklin Delano Roosevelt - Assistant Secretary of the Navy
properties.description: From the start, FDR worked to prepare the navy for the coming war, and was troubled that others did not see it his way.
properties.park2: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site

properties.name: Charlestown Navy Yard
properties.description: Thousands of workers built, repaired, and refitted naval vessels,  and it was the assembly point for destroyers heading out to sea at the outbreak of war.

properties.name: Training for Trench Warfare
properties.description: The brutality of trench warfare in the Civil War was but a tiny preview of the horrors to come in World War I, just fifty years later.

properties.name: Coastal Defense: Fort Hancock during World War I
properties.description: When the US declared war on Germany in 1917, coastal fortifications like Fort Hancock quickly sprung into action to defend the nation against possible threats. The fort activated from a sleepy post to a center of wartime mobilization in a matter of months.

properties.name: The DH-4 Liberty Plane at War and in Peace
properties.description: The DH-4 Liberty plane, manufactured from Sitka spruce logged from the forests of the Pacific Northwest, played a significant role both in battle and after the war.

properties.name: Innovative Defenses at Fort Tilden and Rockaway Naval Air Station during WWI
properties.description: Part of a larger coastal defense system dating to the 18th century, Fort Tilden and Rockaway Naval Air Station helped protect the homeland during World War I against some of the most advanced weapons systems of the time.

properties.name: The Statue of Liberty in Recruitment and War Bonds Posters
properties.description: When the US entered into World War I, the government was faced with the dilemma of converting and funding a standing army to armed forces. The solution enacted were propaganda campaigns with intense recruiting and fundraising appeals that employed the Statue of Liberty as the symbol of American freedom. The Statue appeared in poster images with banner logos designed to appeal to the public’s sense of nationalism, competition, guilt, fear, revenge and social standing.

properties.name: Closing the Door on Immigration
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: US participation in World War I fanned the flames of anti-immigrant sentiment, despite the fact that many immigrants served with distinction in the US military.

properties.name: Immigration and the Great War
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: During the decade leading up to the war, an average of 1 million immigrants per year arrived in the United States, with about three-quarters of them entering through the Ellis Island immigration station in New York Harbor. By 1918, a trickle of only 110,618 people were arriving in the United States.

properties.name: The War in Popular Music: Irving Berlin
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: One of Ellis Island’s most famous immigrants provided the soundtrack to America’s participation in the First World War. Irving Berlin, a popular songwriter, produced patriotic popular music to inspire soldiers and to divert those who needed a break from wartime concerns.

properties.name: Departing and Arriving US Soldiers View the Statue of Liberty
properties.description: For some US soldiers shipping off overseas, the journey to the European battle fields began with departure from the port of Hoboken, New Jersey, into New York Harbor past the Statue of Liberty.

properties.name: Domestic Sabotage: The Explosion at Black Tom Island
properties.park: Ellis Island - Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument
properties.description: In the early morning hours of July 30, 1916, a munitions depot located on Black Tom Island, in Jersey City, NJ, was deliberately sabotaged to prevent supplies from being delivered to Britain and France during World War I. Although this is the closest some would come to combat during the war, the attack rattled at America’s golden door.
properties.park2: Ellis Island Part of Statue of Liberty National Monument

properties.name: Keweenaw Copper at War
properties.description: As World War I entered its second year, the American Institute of Metals trade journal blithely remarked that “[i]t is almost impossible to kill a man in an up-to-date and scientific way without using copper."

properties.name: The Emergence Of The Great Humanitarian
properties.description: Herbert Hoover grew up in a Quaker family and community that valued peace, simplicity, integrity, and service to others. That Herbert Hoover took these beliefs to heart became evident when he emerged from the ghastly carnage of the First World War an American and international hero.

properties.name: The Spruce Production Division
properties.description: From 1917 to 1918, the nationalization of the lumber industry in the Pacific Northwest led to the creation of the Spruce Production Division. This massive war effort employed tens of thousands of soldiers and produced millions of board feet of lumber for the manufacture of airplanes.

properties.name: Preparing For the Great War at Chickamauga Battlefield
properties.description: Beginning in the summer of 1917, the War Department utilized Chickamauga and Chattanooga National Military Park as a training ground for thousands of soldiers preparing to go to France. By the end of the war, six miles of training trenches crisscrossed the battlefield and 60,000 men had trained as officers, engineers, and medical personnel.

properties.name: Pershing Park
properties.description: Pershing led American forces to victory in World War I. He resisted calls to distribute American forces among Allied units, preferring to preserve the fighting integrity of American units. The A.E.F.s bravery remains immortalized here upon engraved granite panels as an enduring testimony of the American spirit to later generations.

properties.name: 'Temporary' War Department Buildings
properties.description: Where visitors now stroll through memorials and green spaces, a huge collection of temporary office buildings once stood.

properties.name: Women's Suffrage and WWI
properties.description: Women’s fight for the right to vote was in its final years, but in the heavy sacrifice and a changing understanding of the meaning of democracy the war brought, the movement had found a renewed energy and enthusiasm during World War I.

properties.name: District of Columbia War Memorial
properties.description: The DC War Memorial honors DC's residents who gave their lives in the Great War.

properties.name: Camp Sherman, Ohio's WWI Soldier Factory
properties.description: Built in only a few months, immediately after America's entry into World War I, this military cantonment in Chillicothe, Ohio quickly became one of the largest constructed for the war effort. Although its gates were only open for three years, Camp Sherman trained hundreds of thousands of soldiers and would send one army division to Europe before the end of the war.

properties.name: Sabotage and Naval Preparedness in Charleston
properties.description: Before the United States declared war on Germany, entering the Great War, an act of naval sabotage brought the war to Charleston Harbor. The German vessel would be raised and converted to an American naval vessel, the USS Houston, thereby linking sabotage to naval preparedness and increased production on the homefront.

properties.name: Camp Sherman Recreation
properties.description: Training to become a U.S. Soldier was (and still is) a rigorous task that often lasted all day. It was challenging to all involved, both physically and mentally. While training was the key purpose of the thousands of soldiers being at Camp Sherman, they did have some downtime from all of the rigors of becoming a soldier. Recreation at the camp played an important part in maintaining physical and mental well-being.

properties.name: Captain Harry Truman
properties.park: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
properties.description: Long before serving as the 33rd President of the United States, Harry S Truman served his country on the front lines of World War I.

properties.name: Souvenirs of War
properties.park: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
properties.description: “Trench art” is any decorative item made by soldiers, prisoners of war or civilians directly linked to armed conflict or its consequences. It offers an insight not only to their feelings and emotions about the war, but also their surroundings and the materials they had available to them.

properties.name: Thomas Edison and Military Preparedness
properties.description: As new technologies changed military conflict during World War I, Thomas Edison called for industrial preparedness, experimented on some of the Navy's most difficult technical problems and helped the U.S. government prepare for future wars by advocating the creation of the Naval Research Laboratory.

properties.name: The Buffalo Soldiers in WWI
properties.park: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument
properties.description: After years of fighting at home and abroad for a country that held mixed feelings for them, many expected the Buffalo Soldiers to be deployed to France in 1917 to help fight in WWI. However, the regular Army regiments of the Buffalo Soldiers would be found nowhere near France during WWI. Find out about the "other" Buffalo Soldiers who would take their place with the American Expeditionary Forces in France.

properties.name: Private Albert Cooper and the 318th Engineers at Vancouver Barracks
properties.description: On April 2, 1918, at the age of 21, Albert “Abbie” Cooper of Hood River, Oregon, enlisted in the United States Army as a Private and was assigned to Company D, 318th Engineers. Cooper joined his regiment at Vancouver Barracks, where they had been training for several weeks.

properties.name: The Conspicuous Absence of the Wright Family at the U.S. outset of WWI
properties.park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
properties.description: As war with Germany proved to be inevitable, the U.S. entered the world-wide conflict in April of 1917. However, from the outset of the U.S. entry into the war, one notable family was conspicuously absent from the outset. While the U.S. prepared for war, the Wright family had their focus on something entirely different.

Fighting the enemy in combat on the battlefields of France was a horror in and of itself, but in the fall of 1918, soldiers on the battlefield and every other person on the planet would be facing off against an invisible killer that would devastate the world population. The Spanish Influenza Pandemic of 1918 tallied a staggering amount of victims and remains the most deadly viral outbreak in the history of the planet.
properties.name: The Spanish Influenza Pandemic of 1918 at Camp Sherman
Harry S Truman and the Influences of His Service in World War I
properties.park: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
properties.description: Harry Truman is the only US president to see combat during the First World War. His war experience affected the course of his life and influenced his rise to the presidency in two important ways: he discovered a leadership ability he hadn’t known that he possessed, and he garnered a significant political base that supported him in his rise though political ranks.

properties.name: Defending America’s Coasts
properties.description: On July 19, 1918, submarine U-156 sank the USS San Diego 10 miles offshore of Fire Island.
properties.park2: National Parks of New York Harbor

properties.name: These Great Present & Future Problems: Erica Thorp and WWI French War Orphans
properties.park: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
properties.description: Soon after the United States entered the war in 1917, Erica Thorp put her life in America on hold to travel to France to work at a colony for orphaned boys. She found immense pleasure in nurturing these boys and providing for them when no one else was able.

properties.name: Advancements in Medical Care during World War I
properties.park: Fort McHenry National Monument and Historic Shrine
properties.description: The advanced weaponry of World War I, such as chemical agents and trench warfare, created a uniquely afflicted veteran population not seen before. The medical facilities at the fort included several departments that pioneered new treatment strategies and new technology that were designed to tailor to the needs of the victims of this modern war.

properties.name: The War Reaches Home: Attack on Cape Cod
properties.description: On July 21, 1918, New Englanders found themselves with World War I on their doorsteps in the form of a German U-boat attack off Cape Cod, at the town of Orleans. During the attack, some of the shells fired from the submarine landed on Nauset Beach, making this the first attack on the US mainland since the War of 1812 and the only attack on US soil during World War I.

properties.name: Dayton, Aviation, and the First World War
properties.description: When the war began in Europe, the United States military had very few airplanes – only six airplanes, and fourteen trained pilots, were available for use. America realized she needed to strengthen its air power, and quickly.
properties.park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

properties.name: First Division Monument
properties.description: The First Division Monument sits on a plaza in President's Park, west of the White House and south of the Eisenhower Executive Office Building (EEOB) at the corner of 17th Street and State Place, NW. The monument was conceived by the Society of the First Division, the veteran's organization of the U.S. Army's First Division, to honor the valiant efforts of the soldiers who fought in World War I.

properties.name: Storer College Students in World War I
properties.description: Storer College was founded in 1867 and was the first institution of higher learning for African Americans in West Virginia. Over 100 students and alumni of the school enlisted and contributed to the United States' efforts during the Great War.

properties.name: Second Division Memorial
properties.description: Dedicated in 1936 to honor the Second Division's fallen from World War I, the memorial was expanded in 1962 to include World War II and the Korean War.

properties.name: General John J. Pershing
properties.description: Pershing became a major-general just before the United States entered World War I on April 6, 1917. This time he was appointed over the heads of 5 other major-generals, to become the commander of the AEF.

properties.name: Women in World War I
properties.description: Five million men were mobilized for service in the Great War. Over nine million women mobilized themselves.

properties.name: Alice Longfellow and the American Ambulance Field Service
properties.park: Longfellow House Washington's Headquarters National Historic Site
properties.description: Alice Longfellow, the poet’s daughter, contributed to several organizations providing humanitarian relief over the course of the war and beyond.

properties.name: YMCA Service Clubs at Vancouver Barracks During World War I
properties.description: For soldiers stationed at Vancouver Barracks during World War I, many of whom were working at the Spruce Mill, three YMCA buildings at the post provided places of relaxation, recreation, and personal enrichment. These facilities were staffed by the YMCA, which also provided books, magazines, writing materials, entertainment, educational programs, and religious services conducted by military chaplains.

properties.name: Robert Simmons
properties.description: When Robert Simmons, an African American man from Savannah, Georgia, was brought to the foggy, windswept island of Alcatraz in the winter of 1918, he was thrown into the “hole,” a pitch-dark dungeon cell with slimy walls, crawling with rats. He was held there for 14 days.
